title: 2025 Honda Prologue
excerpt: The Prologue has competitive range and a roomy cabin, making it a good electric SUV, but it doesn't feel like a Honda over the road.
text: HomeHondaPrologueHondaHIGHSCompetitive range, quick-ish fast-charging capability, roomy inside.LOWSNot very athletic, not particularly quick, its Chevy roots are showing.VERDICTThe Prologue makes a good electric SUV, it just doesn't feel like a Honda from behind the wheel.SpecsEPA Est. Range 283–308 Miles Drivetrain Front-Wheel Drive, All-Wheel Drive Limited Warranty 3 Years/36,000 Miles By David GluckmanOverview Honda needed a way to quickly get back into the U.S. EV market and chose to partner with General Motors to produce the Prologue SUV. It borrows its platform, battery, and motors from the Chevy Blazer EV, giving front-drive models 220 horsepower and all-wheel-drive versions 300 horses. Aside from styling and the badge atop the dealership, perhaps the biggest difference between the Prologue and the Blazer EV is that the Honda offers Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, something that's not available on any newer GM EVs. There's not much differentiation in the way these EV step-siblings drive, and the switchgear in the Honda's cabin was clearly taken from the GM parts bin. While the Prologue is a competent performer, it isn't imbued with the driving verve the Japanese automaker is known for. Its main non-GM competitor is the three-row Kia EV9. Acura, Honda's luxury brand, also gets a GM-based EV—the ZDX—which borrows its more powerful motors from the Cadillac Lyriq.What's New for 2025?For its second model year, the Prologue gets updates including a more powerful front-mounted electric motor, bringing total output to 220 hp for front-wheel-drive models and 300 hp for all-wheel-drive models. Its range estimates also go up, with the FWD Prologue now rated for 308 miles on a charge and the AWD model rated at 294 miles. Pricing and Which One to Buy The price of the 2025 Honda Prologue starts at $48,850 and goes up to $59,350 depending on the trim and options.Honda's traditional EX, Touring, and Elite trims are offered here, and even the entry-level Prologue comes nicely equipped with heated front seats, dual-zone automatic climate control, and wireless smartphone charging. But we think the Touring model is worth the upgrade, as it adds leather upholstery, a 12-speaker Bose stereo, and memory seat settings. We would, however, stick with the front-wheel-drive model as it boasts the highest estimated driving range at 296 miles per charge.EV Motor, Power, and PerformanceThe Prologue can be had with either a 220-hp single motor and front-wheel drive or with two motors that combine for 300 horsepower and all-wheel drive. During our test drive, the dual-motor version provided adequate acceleration but the Prologue lacks the punch of rivals such as the Hyundai Ioniq 5 and the Kia EV6. We haven't yet driven the 2025 model, which has slightly more power than before. The Prologue's road manners are even-tempered, too, with a smooth ride and steady handling, but its steering lacks the tactile feel you get in other Hondas. We like the adjustable regenerative braking system, which can slow the car at varying levels when you lift off the accelerator; single-pedal driving is possible, and there's a handy paddle on the steering wheel that increases the level of regen on demand to slow the car further.0–60-MPH TimesIn our testing, the all-wheel-drive, dual-motor Elite model got to 60 mph in 5.9 seconds. We haven't yet tested the updated 2025 model with its more powerful electric motor.Range, Charging, and Battery LifeAll Prologue models come with an 85.0-kWh battery pack sourced from General Motors. The single-motor front-wheel-drive model has an EPA-estimated 308-mile driving range, while the dual-motor all-wheel-drive version sacrifices some of that range for peppier acceleration. All-wheel-drive versions of the EX and Touring trims are rated for 294 miles per charge, while the range-topping Elite carries a 283-mile estimate. In our testing of the 2024 model, the Elite AWD achieved a real-world range of 240 miles. We haven't yet tested the updated 2025 model on this real-world range test. The Prologue can juice its battery on a DC fast-charger at a max rate of 155 kW, and Honda sells a home charging kit should you wish to refill the battery conveniently in your own garage.Fuel Economy and Real-World MPGeFront-wheel-drive versions of the EX and Touring trims are the most efficient according to EPA estimates, both earning ratings of 113 MPGe city and 94 MPGe highway. On our 75-mph highway fuel-economy route, the 2024 Prologue Elite achieved 75 MPGe, underperforming its highway rating of 84 MPGe. We haven't yet tested the updated 2025 model. For more information about the Prologue’s fuel economy, visit the EPA's website.Interior, Comfort, and CargoWhile there are clues to the Prologue's Chevrolet roots inside, Honda made some changes to infuse the cabin with a design that looks recognizable as one of its own. Its simplified dashboard has fewer flourishes than the Blazer EV's, as the Chevy's round vents, brightly colored surfaces, and tilted infotainment display don’t make their way into the Honda. Instead, the Prologue's layout is vaguely similar to those of other Hondas, with a clutter-free design rendered in muted tones. The Chevy's buttons, switches, and knobs do carry over, which not only seem out of place in the Honda showroom but also are awkward to use. The Prologue's wheelbase is 8 inches longer than the CR-V's, and the EV model is 5 inches wider too, which creates a roomier cabin with additional space for cargo.Infotainment and ConnectivityStanding tall and proud in the middle of the Prologue's dashboard is an 11.3-inch infotainment touchscreen. Wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto are included—unlike on the Blazer EV, which doesn't offer these smartphone-mirroring features—as is an in-dash navigation system that uses Google Maps. An 11.0-inch digital gauge display and a wireless smartphone charging pad are also standard features; a head-up display is available but only on the top-spec Elite trim. A 12-speaker Bose stereo system with tweeter speakers in the Prologue's A-pillars is standard on Touring and Elite models.Safety and Driver-Assistance FeaturesAll Prologue models come with a suite of driver-assistance features called Honda Sensing. This package includes basic systems such as automated emergency braking and lane-departure warning, as well as more advanced tech such as lane-keeping assist, adaptive cruise control, and traffic-sign recognition. For more information about the Prologue’s crash-test results, visit the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) and Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) websites. Key safety features include: Standard automated emergency braking with pedestrian detection Standard lane-departure warning with lane-keeping assist Standard adaptive cruise controlWarranty and Maintenance CoverageThe Prologue comes with the same warranty that's standard on all other new Honda models, which is similar to what's offered on other electric SUVs from mainstream automakers. Honda's usual coverage package also includes two years of complimentary scheduled maintenance as a bonus. Limited warranty covers three years or 36,000 miles Powertrain warranty covers five years or 60,000 miles Electric components are covered for eight years or 100,000 miles Complimentary maintenance is covered for two years or 24,000 milesSpecificationsSpecifications 2024 Honda Prologue Elite AWD Vehicle Type: front- and rear-motor, all-wheel-drive, 5-passenger, 4-door wagon PRICE Base/As Tested: $59,295/$59,750 Options: North Shore Pearl paint, $455 POWERTRAIN Front Motor: permanent-magnet synchronous AC, 241 hp, 225 lb-ft Rear Motor: induction AC, 90 hp, 121 lb-ft Combined Power: 288 hp Combined Torque: 333 lb-ft Battery Pack: liquid-cooled lithium-ion, 85.0 kWh Onboard Charger: 11.5 kW Peak DC Fast-Charge Rate: 150 kW Transmissions, F/R: direct-drive CHASSIS Suspension, F/R: multilink/multilink Brakes, F/R: 12.6-in vented disc/13.6-in disc Tires: Bridgestone Alenza A/S 02 Enliten 275/45R-21 107H M+S TPC Spec 3187 B-Seal DIMENSIONS Wheelbase: 121.8 in Length: 192.0 in Width: 78.3 in Height: 65.2 in Passenger Volume, F/R: 54/48 ft3 Cargo Volume, Behind F/R: 55/24 ft3 Curb Weight: 5268 lb C/D TEST RESULTS 60 mph: 5.9 sec 1/4-Mile: 14.8 sec @ 93 mph 100 mph: 16.6 sec Results above omit 1-ft rollout of 0.3 sec. Rolling Start, 5–60 mph: 6.0 sec Top Gear, 30–50 mph: 2.5 sec Top Gear, 50–70 mph: 3.9 sec Top Speed (gov ltd): 112 mph Braking, 70–0 mph: 186 ft Roadholding, 300-ft Skidpad: 0.80 g C/D FUEL ECONOMY AND CHARGING Observed: 75 MPGe 75-mph Highway Range: 240 mi Average DC Fast-Charge Rate, 10–90%: 97 kW DC Fast-Charge Time, 10–90%: 48 min EPA FUEL ECONOMY Combined/City/Highway: 92/99/84 MPGe Range: 273 mi C/D TESTING EXPLAINEDMore Features and SpecsShopping ToolsWhat's My Car Worth?Car and Driver values are calculated from the same Black Book® data dealers use to appraise vehicles.Insurance MarketplaceSee what you can save on car insurance.Auto Loans & FinancingOur finance experts answer any questions you may have about financing a vehicle.Similar VehiclesEPA Est. html:
1. Home
  2. Honda
  3. Prologue

    HIGHS

  • Competitive range, quick-ish fast-charging capability, roomy inside.

    • LOWS

  • Not very athletic, not particularly quick, its Chevy roots are showing.

    • VERDICT

  • The Prologue makes a good electric SUV, it just doesn't feel like a Honda from behind the wheel.

Specs

EPA Est. Range

283–308 Miles

Drivetrain

Front-Wheel Drive, All-Wheel Drive

Limited Warranty

3 Years/36,000 Miles

By David Gluckman

Overview

Honda needed a way to quickly get back into the U.S. EV market and chose to partner with General Motors to produce the Prologue SUV. It borrows its platform, battery, and motors from the Chevy Blazer EV, giving front-drive models 220 horsepower and all-wheel-drive versions 300 horses. Aside from styling and the badge atop the dealership, perhaps the biggest difference between the Prologue and the Blazer EV is that the Honda offers Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, something that's not available on any newer GM EVs. There's not much differentiation in the way these EV step-siblings drive, and the switchgear in the Honda's cabin was clearly taken from the GM parts bin. While the Prologue is a competent performer, it isn't imbued with the driving verve the Japanese automaker is known for. Its main non-GM competitor is the three-row Kia EV9. Acura, Honda's luxury brand, also gets a GM-based EV—the ZDX—which borrows its more powerful motors from the Cadillac Lyriq.

What's New for 2025?

For its second model year, the Prologue gets updates including a more powerful front-mounted electric motor, bringing total output to 220 hp for front-wheel-drive models and 300 hp for all-wheel-drive models. Its range estimates also go up, with the FWD Prologue now rated for 308 miles on a charge and the AWD model rated at 294 miles.

Pricing and Which One to Buy

The price of the 2025 Honda Prologue starts at $48,850 and goes up to $59,350 depending on the trim and options.

    Honda's traditional EX, Touring, and Elite trims are offered here, and even the entry-level Prologue comes nicely equipped with heated front seats, dual-zone automatic climate control, and wireless smartphone charging. But we think the Touring model is worth the upgrade, as it adds leather upholstery, a 12-speaker Bose stereo, and memory seat settings. We would, however, stick with the front-wheel-drive model as it boasts the highest estimated driving range at 296 miles per charge.

    EV Motor, Power, and Performance

    The Prologue can be had with either a 220-hp single motor and front-wheel drive or with two motors that combine for 300 horsepower and all-wheel drive. During our test drive, the dual-motor version provided adequate acceleration but the Prologue lacks the punch of rivals such as the Hyundai Ioniq 5 and the Kia EV6. We haven't yet driven the 2025 model, which has slightly more power than before. The Prologue's road manners are even-tempered, too, with a smooth ride and steady handling, but its steering lacks the tactile feel you get in other Hondas. We like the adjustable regenerative braking system, which can slow the car at varying levels when you lift off the accelerator; single-pedal driving is possible, and there's a handy paddle on the steering wheel that increases the level of regen on demand to slow the car further.

    0–60-MPH Times

    In our testing, the all-wheel-drive, dual-motor Elite model got to 60 mph in 5.9 seconds. We haven't yet tested the updated 2025 model with its more powerful electric motor.

      Range, Charging, and Battery Life

      All Prologue models come with an 85.0-kWh battery pack sourced from General Motors. The single-motor front-wheel-drive model has an EPA-estimated 308-mile driving range, while the dual-motor all-wheel-drive version sacrifices some of that range for peppier acceleration. All-wheel-drive versions of the EX and Touring trims are rated for 294 miles per charge, while the range-topping Elite carries a 283-mile estimate. In our testing of the 2024 model, the Elite AWD achieved a real-world range of 240 miles. We haven't yet tested the updated 2025 model on this real-world range test. The Prologue can juice its battery on a DC fast-charger at a max rate of 155 kW, and Honda sells a home charging kit should you wish to refill the battery conveniently in your own garage.

      Fuel Economy and Real-World MPGe

      Front-wheel-drive versions of the EX and Touring trims are the most efficient according to EPA estimates, both earning ratings of 113 MPGe city and 94 MPGe highway. On our 75-mph highway fuel-economy route, the 2024 Prologue Elite achieved 75 MPGe, underperforming its highway rating of 84 MPGe. We haven't yet tested the updated 2025 model. For more information about the Prologue’s fuel economy, visit the EPA's website.

      Interior, Comfort, and Cargo

      While there are clues to the Prologue's Chevrolet roots inside, Honda made some changes to infuse the cabin with a design that looks recognizable as one of its own. Its simplified dashboard has fewer flourishes than the Blazer EV's, as the Chevy's round vents, brightly colored surfaces, and tilted infotainment display don’t make their way into the Honda. Instead, the Prologue's layout is vaguely similar to those of other Hondas, with a clutter-free design rendered in muted tones. The Chevy's buttons, switches, and knobs do carry over, which not only seem out of place in the Honda showroom but also are awkward to use. The Prologue's wheelbase is 8 inches longer than the CR-V's, and the EV model is 5 inches wider too, which creates a roomier cabin with additional space for cargo.

        Infotainment and Connectivity

        Standing tall and proud in the middle of the Prologue's dashboard is an 11.3-inch infotainment touchscreen. Wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto are included—unlike on the Blazer EV, which doesn't offer these smartphone-mirroring features—as is an in-dash navigation system that uses Google Maps. An 11.0-inch digital gauge display and a wireless smartphone charging pad are also standard features; a head-up display is available but only on the top-spec Elite trim. A 12-speaker Bose stereo system with tweeter speakers in the Prologue's A-pillars is standard on Touring and Elite models.

          Safety and Driver-Assistance Features

          All Prologue models come with a suite of driver-assistance features called Honda Sensing. This package includes basic systems such as automated emergency braking and lane-departure warning, as well as more advanced tech such as lane-keeping assist, adaptive cruise control, and traffic-sign recognition. For more information about the Prologue’s crash-test results, visit the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) and Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) websites. Key safety features include:

          • Standard automated emergency braking with pedestrian detection
          • Standard lane-departure warning with lane-keeping assist
          • Standard adaptive cruise control

          Warranty and Maintenance Coverage

          The Prologue comes with the same warranty that's standard on all other new Honda models, which is similar to what's offered on other electric SUVs from mainstream automakers. Honda's usual coverage package also includes two years of complimentary scheduled maintenance as a bonus.

          • Limited warranty covers three years or 36,000 miles
          • Powertrain warranty covers five years or 60,000 miles
          • Electric components are covered for eight years or 100,000 miles
          • Complimentary maintenance is covered for two years or 24,000 miles

          Specifications

          Specifications

          2024 Honda Prologue Elite AWD
          Vehicle Type: front- and rear-motor, all-wheel-drive, 5-passenger, 4-door wagon

          PRICE
           Base/As Tested: $59,295/$59,750
          Options: North Shore Pearl paint, $455

          POWERTRAIN
           Front Motor: permanent-magnet synchronous AC, 241 hp, 225 lb-ft
          Rear Motor: induction AC, 90 hp, 121 lb-ft
          Combined Power: 288 hp
          Combined Torque: 333 lb-ft
          Battery Pack: liquid-cooled lithium-ion, 85.0 kWh
          Onboard Charger: 11.5 kW
          Peak DC Fast-Charge Rate: 150 kW
          Transmissions, F/R: direct-drive

          CHASSIS
           Suspension, F/R: multilink/multilink
          Brakes, F/R: 12.6-in vented disc/13.6-in disc
          Tires: Bridgestone Alenza A/S 02 Enliten
          275/45R-21 107H M+S TPC Spec 3187 B-Seal

          DIMENSIONS
           Wheelbase: 121.8 in
          Length: 192.0 in
          Width: 78.3 in
          Height: 65.2 in
          Passenger Volume, F/R: 54/48 ft3
          Cargo Volume, Behind F/R: 55/24 ft3
          Curb Weight: 5268 lb

          C/D TEST RESULTS
           60 mph: 5.9 sec
          1/4-Mile: 14.8 sec @ 93 mph
          100 mph: 16.6 sec
          Results above omit 1-ft rollout of 0.3 sec.
          Rolling Start, 5–60 mph: 6.0 sec
          Top Gear, 30–50 mph: 2.5 sec
          Top Gear, 50–70 mph: 3.9 sec
          Top Speed (gov ltd): 112 mph
          Braking, 70–0 mph: 186 ft
          Roadholding, 300-ft Skidpad: 0.80 g

          C/D FUEL ECONOMY AND CHARGING
           Observed: 75 MPGe
          75-mph Highway Range: 240 mi
          Average DC Fast-Charge Rate, 10–90%: 97 kW
          DC Fast-Charge Time, 10–90%: 48 min

          EPA FUEL ECONOMY
           Combined/City/Highway: 92/99/84 MPGe
          Range: 273 mi

          C/D TESTING EXPLAINED
